posts.name: Matthew Boyer
posts.cooked:
I prefer IntelliJ over Visual Studio, so I was wondering if anyone uses it.  There is an unofficial FRC plugin that does use WPILib, but I’m not sure if you can deploy to the NI RoboRio.

Edit: While using VS Code, when I did Shift+F5 I  saw it was running a gradlew deploy command, but I don’t know if there is a deploy shortcut in IntelliJ or how that works.

Thanks!

posts.name: connor.worley
posts.cooked: You can deploy using whatever editor you want, just run ./gradlew deploy in a shell

posts.name: retrodaredevil
posts.cooked: Last time I used the unofficial plugin, it was great for viewing the logs of your code running on the robot, but I don’t remember uploading with it directly. Just used the command line for uploading.

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked: Going to assume you are on Windows. The full shell command that is generated by the deploy button is cmd.exe /d /c gradlew deploy -PteamNumber=1477 --offline -Dorg.gradle.java.home="C:\Users\Public\wpilib\2021\jdk" . The part specifying the Java home is pretty important, replace the path with the path to the JDK in your WPILib folder. Replace PteamNumber with yours obviously, but idk if you even need that option at all.

posts.name: Yu Liu
posts.cooked: We used IntelliJ a lot - the current control system software is based on Gradle, which is already integrated into the IDE - look up how to use Gradle with IntelliJ, then just select the deploy task from the toolbar to run it

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: When you generate a project with the unofficial plugin (and maybe import it to, I am not sure) it will add the deploy gradle task to the run configurations.

posts.name: Matthew Boyer
posts.cooked: Is there a log directly in the IDE like with VS Code?

posts.name: Yu Liu
posts.cooked: you could use the riolog command built into Gradle (and available in the toolbar)

posts.name: Matthew Boyer
posts.cooked: The “and available in the toolbar” post is exactly what I would need.  Thanks for letting me know!

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

suggested_topics.title: Swerve wheels spinning different directions after assigning CanCoder ID's
suggested_topics.excerpt: We solved it. Our cancoder ID’s were not aligned with our spark max id’s therefore causing the issue
